The 14 units of the Pembina Valley WMA protect wildlife habitat and also play an important role in preventing soil erosion in this ravine landscape.

The valley is a very popular spot with birders who gather to see the spring migration of raptors along the wide and deep valley. The steep valley walls create an updraft, which many species will use to take them north when there is a south wind. Peak migrations take place between late March and mid-April. Some of the species you can see are bald and golden eagles, turkey vultures, thousands of red-tailed hawks, northern harriers, rough-legged hawks, ferruginous and red-shouldered hawks, even peregrine falcons.

Nesting in the area are many bird species on the northern fringe of their range – indigo bunting, brown thrasher, eastern towhee, orchard oriole and lark sparrow to name a few. The Pembina Valley is also excellent habitat for deer, moose, grouse, waterfowl and other wildlife. Watch for wild turkeys that survive the winters on the warm south facing slopes of the valley.

Each unit of the WMA has its own features. From east to west they are broken into three groups Lower, Upper and Western.

Lower units
  • Point Douglas Unit, along the border near Windygates, protects three parcels of aspen-oak forest habitat.
  • Little Pembina Unit, south of Darlingford, protects an aspen-oak forest along the Little Pembina Creek.
  • Mowbray Unit, north of Mowbray, protects three parcels of aspen-oak forest and an area formerly cultivated, but now reseeded to grassland.
  • Snowflake Unit, east of Snowflake, protects two parcels of riparian habitat along Snowflake Creek.
  • Riverdale Unit, northeast of Snowflake, takes in a mix of riparian woodland and mixed-grass prairie habitat.

Upper units
  • La Rivière Unit, south of La Rivière, is mostly upland habitat of aspen-oak forest and grassland meadows, but also includes riparian habitat along a creek.
  • Grassy Lake Unit, southwest of Somerset, protects an aspen-oak forest and Grassy Lake Marsh.
  • Wood Bay Unit, east of PTH 34, is a mix of aspen and balsam poplar with a few spruce, and forage fields. There was a tornado in 2005 that flattened much of the forest. You will find deer and wild turkey.
  • Floral Unit, on the south end of Swan Lake, includes forage fields, aspen-oak forest along the valley slopes and a marsh on the valley floor.
  • Stuartville Unit, between Rock Lake and Swan Lake, protects a mix of uplands and valley slopes of aspen-oak forest.
  • Marringhurst Unit, between Rock Lake and Swan Lake, protects a combination of uplands and riverbottom habitat. Mixed-grass prairie and aspen-oak forest are found along the valley slopes. A managed marsh with dense nesting cover was developed on the valley floor beside the river.
    • ,
Western units
  • Neelin Unit, on the south shore of Rock Lake, protects a mature forest of aspen, oak and birch on the valley slope.
  • West Derby Unit, on the west shore of Lorne Lake, protects two parcels of upland habitat with a mix of aspen-oak and grasslands.
  • Pelican Lake Marsh Unit, on the north end of Pelican Lake, is almost entirely wetland. It protects nesting and staging habitat for waterfowl.

If you are wondering where a name for a WMA comes from, some are named for towns or school districts that were once there. These names are used as a celebration of early Manitoba history – they keep the names alive when the town or school has gone.

The twelve units of the Upper Assiniboine WMA stretch from north of St. Lazare, south to Miniota and southeast to the Oak Lake area. These upper reaches of the Assiniboine River valley have an amazing diversity of wildlife.

Of particular note are the many neo-tropical birds. Look for orange-crowned warbler, yellow-throated vireo, eastern wood-pewee, lark sparrow and mountain bluebird. The valley also provides a good view of migrating hawks and bald eagles in March and October as they glide on the updrafts created by the valley. There is plenty of good habitat for deer, grouse and waterfowl in these widely separated parcels of land.

To help you plan your visit to the Upper Assiniboine WMA, we have grouped the 12 units into three areas – northern, central and southern.

The northern section includes the Gambler Unit, southwest of Binscarth. In the Gambler Unit you will find a combination of colourful mixed-grass prairie and old aspen-oak forest.

The central area includes seven units.
  • The Bird Tail Creek Unit, north of Willen has a deep ravine that challenges hikers and provides cover for deer. The Bird Tail Creek is an attractive area that includes both forest and mixed-grass prairie on the uplands.
  • The Uno Unit is west of the town of Uno on the eastern edge of the Bird Tail Creek First Nation Reserve. The diversity of protected habitat includes riparian areas, mixed-grass prairie and aspen-oak forest.
  • The Miniota Unit, northwest of Miniota sits on the edge of the Assiniboine River. You will find an old oxbow lake there demonstrating how the meandering river often changes course, choosing a shortcut across one of its meanders, leaving the oxbow stranded. The valley slopes are covered in aspen-oak forest, which provides food and cover for white-tailed deer.
  • The Arrow River Unit, northeast of Miniota, is largely a wetland area. The wetlands provide nurseries for waterfowl and migration staging areas in spring and fall. This is a good area for birding in spring and summer. Watch for hunters in fall.
  • The Willen Unit, south of the village of Willen, is a series of small blocks of land. They contain bluffs of aspen and meadows of mixed-grass prairie. Some parts of this unit were previously cultivated but have been reclaimed for habitat by planting them to grass.
  • The Two Creeks Unit is west of the village of Two Creeks. It protects habitat for deer and grouse by providing both mixed-grass prairie and aspen bluffs. Areas that were once cultivated have been reclaimed by seeding to grasses.
  • The Reeder Unit, southwest of Miniota, is incised with steep ravines and the slopes of the Assiniboine Valley. Niso Creek runs through the unit. Forage fields and shelterbelts provide food and cover for deer. The remainder of the unit is a mix of grassland, aspen bluffs and bur oak on the valley slopes.
The southern area includes four units.
  • The Mayne Unit, north of Alexander, protects deer habitat. It is a mix of former farm land that has been seeded to tame forage and planted with shelterbelts; and native grasslands interspersed with aspen-oak bluffs.
  • Pleasant Plains Unit, east of Routledge, extends into a large meander of the Assiniboine River. The land is low along the river with steep banks. A managed wetland was developed in cooperation with Ducks Unlimited Canada to provide waterfowl habitat. Dense nesting cover and shelterbelts were planted to enhance the quality of wildlife habitat.
  • The Routledge Unit, west of the town of Oak Lake, is a partially stabilized sand dunes complex. The dunes are covered with mixed-grass prairie and aspen-oak forest. You might also find the threatened western spiderwort if you look carefully in June when it blooms. There is also oil under the Routledge Unit and you will see several oil wells pumping oil to the surface.
  • The Runnymede Unit, southeast of the town of Oak Lake, is relatively flat with some stabilized sand dunes. The vegetation is a mix of aspen bluffs and native grasslands.

The Whitemud Watershed WMA is made up of 12 widely spaced units within the Whitemud River basin. They stretch from Trehern to McCreary.

The Whitemud Watershed WMA provides important habitat for deer, upland game birds, amphibians and other wildlife that require mixed-grass prairie and aspen-oak stands.

To help you plan your visit we have grouped the Whitemud Watershed WMA units into four areas – north, central, southern and Lower Assiniboine Unit.

The northern units are a number of small parcels of land in the Gladstone-McCreary area. They include the Edington, Oak Leaf, Robins Ridge, Grass River, Glenella and Waldglen units. These units are largely mixed-grass prairie, aspen forest and formerly cultivated areas that have been seeded to forage and grasses.

The central units are northeast of Carberry. They include the Edrans and Hummerston units. The Edrans unit is the larger of the two and is broken into a number of parcels of land. The habitat is a mixed-grass prairie and aspen-oak forest on sand dune formations. Some of these units are sitting on the edge of the Manitoba Escarpment.

The southern units of the Whitemud Watershed WMA are in the area south of MacGregor. They include the Pratt, Clairmont, and Chipping Hill units. Aspen-oak forests dominate these small parcels of land on rolling hills of an old glacial moraine.

The Lower Assiniboine Unit includes 10 parcels of land along the Assiniboine River. This unit protects riparian habitat that is so important to wildlife. A spin off is that protecting the habitat also helps protect the river by preventing erosion and filtering runoff. Portions of this unit were once cultivated and have been reclaimed with plantings of grasses and forage. Other parcels are native mixed-grass prairie with underlying sand dune formations.

The Parkland WMA is made up of four separate units that range from the southern edge of Riding Mountain National Park, southwest to the St. Lazare area. The Parkland WMA protects habitat critical for breeding and migrating neo-tropical birds such as the eastern towhees. Deer are common.

The four units have a diversity of habitat including wetlands, prairie grasslands and mature forests.
  • The Buckleyville Unit, west of the town of Shoal Lake, has a large wetland that provides good habitat for breeding waterfowl.
  • The Horod Unit, on the southern boundary of Riding Mountain National Park near Lake Audy, has a large area of reclaimed grasslands and several wetlands. This unit provides habitat for waterfowl, moose, elk, deer, black bear and grouse. You might also see a wide variety of warblers, many flycatchers, vireos, thrushes and sparrows.
  • Ruska Rawa Unit, near Rossburn, is hilly with a mature aspen forest. It provides habitat for elk, moose, deer, black bear, grouse and waterbirds.
  • Snake Creek Unit, east of St. Lazare, includes a riparian and grassland habitat ideal for deer, grouse and other prairie wildlife. You may find western and eastern wood peewees in this unit. Look for Cooper's hawk, red-headed woodpecker and yellow-throated vireo.

Tiger Hills WMA consists of three units. The Tiger Hills are another legacy of the ice age. The last great glacier to leave its mark on the land deposited a belt of sand and gravel or end-moraine, forming the Tiger Hills. The rolling topography provides great habitat for white-tailed deer. Grouse take advantage of the combination of native grassland and aspen-oak forest. Waterfowl are abundant in the Mimir and Delta units.

The three units of the Tiger Hills WMA include:
  • Ninette Unit, just north of the town of Ninette. This habitat is predominantly aspen-oak forest with a smattering of native grasslands.
  • Mimir Unit, just south of Glenboro, is rolling topography covered in aspen-oak forest and includes a 30 hectare lake. Watch for wildlife coming to the lake early morning or late evening.
  • Delta Unit, northeast of Pelican Lake, is a combination of aspen-oak forest and riparian areas. Much of the land of this unit was once cultivated and is now used for hay. The riparian zones are good habitat for neo-tropical birds such as the Lincoln's sparrow.

Alonsa is a midsize WMA between Lake Manitoba and Riding Mountain National Park. It was established in 1974 and is largely aspen forest with some native mixed-grass prairie. You can find a variety of shrubs including the some good berry picking areas. Look for bearberry, current, gooseberry, buffaloberry, cranberry, chokecherry and saskatoons, or as some call them, serviceberries.

The Alonsa WMA is an important breeding area for migratory birds, especially songbirds. Listen for the red-eyed, solitary and Philadelphia vireo. Watch for possible sightings of the red-headed woodpecker. The Connecticut warbler is just one of many warblers found here. Sandhill cranes nest along the ridges between the wetlands. Alonsa also provides habitat for other species such as deer, sharp-tailed and ruffed grouse, coyote, fox, ermine, muskrat and the occasional elk or moose.

On the prairie ridge grasslands look for these butterflies – common sulphur, dreamy dusky wing, monarch, northwestern fritillary, ringlet, tiger swallowtail, viceroy and western tailed blue. In June look for the yellow lady's slipper. Other grassland wildflowers to watch for are the meadow and dotted blazingstar, prairie lily, gaillardia and gentian.

A trail network runs through the area in southwest – northeast direction along ridges. Be sure to take along a compass or GPS unit to find your way. From the Ste. Amélie side of the WMA, a short trail leads you to the Medicine Rock interpretive site where you will see a large rock. Around the rock are offerings, such as tobacco, from the First Nations community. Two interpretive signs tell you more about the rock and offerings.

The Alonsa WMA provides a unique blend of natural and cultural history. Not only are there diverse wildlife viewing opportunities, but the Medicine Rock and the Oak Lake Gathering Area provide insights into First Nation's cultural and spiritual traditions.

Basket Lake WMA is north of the upper edge of Lake Manitoba. In the southern section of the WMA you will find the shallow, marshy Basket Lake, a good spot for hunting or wildlife watching. The upland areas around the lake are blanketed with aspen and balsam poplar with willow and some grassland meadows. In other areas of the WMA are stands of jack pine. If you look closely you can see evidence of repeated wildfires, a natural process that helps rejuvenate the habitat.

This remote WMA protects habitat for a diversity of species. Look for elk and deer browsing on the uplands. Moose can be found feeding in the wetlands. Waterfowl are abundant on the lake. Ring-billed gulls and several grebe species nest here and ruffed grouse are common.

Broad Valley WMA is on several parcels of land west of the village of Broad Valley in Manitoba's Interlake. This is Parkland habitat, a combination of open grassland meadows with groves of oak and aspen that give it a park-like setting. Come summer you will find ripe saskatoons and chokecherry lining the edges of aspen stands. Much of the land of the Interlake is marginal farmland, some of which has been reclaimed for wildlife habitat as part of a series of Wildlife Management Areas. The Broad Valley WMA protects important habitat for deer as well as elk. White-tailed deer prefer the edge-habitat that Parklands provide, with its mix of meadows and groves. Broad Valley offers vital winter habitat for the deer and elk, sheltering them from frigid winds while providing exposed grasses to eat on the sunny hillsides.

Other mammals that make their home in the Broad Valley WMA are red fox, black bear and mink. This area of the Interlake is famous for its red-sided garter snake. To find out more about them see Narcisse WMA.

Ruffed and sharp-tailed grouse are both found in the WMA. Ruffed grouse are here year round feeding on buds, berries and insects. The sharp-tails tend to prefer the prairie sites in summer, but move to more sheltered Parklands for winter where they can find food above the snow cover. Songbirds are abundant in spring and summer.

Broad Valley WMA includes Otter Lake, a staging area for waterfowl, shorebirds and pelicans. You will often see a long line of pelicans floating effortlessly overhead on their way to and from feeding grounds.

Throughout the WMA marshy wetlands fill shallows, providing home and feeding grounds to a diversity of wildlife. In spring, the marshes are loud and colourful places. Choruses of frogs and toads call for mates while male birds in mating plumage serenade partners. Nesting around the marsh are green-winged and blue-winged teal, mallards, killdeer, solitary sandpiper and the black tern.

The Old Pioneer Trail runs close to several parcels of the Broad Valley WMA. It starts at Grosse Isle, and following a decommissioned railway, heads north along the Principle Meridian up to Fisher Branch.

Broomhill WMA is tucked into the far southwest corner of the province; in an area of unproductive farmland know as Poverty Plains. While the land was not going to make the pioneers rich, today there is a wealth of bird life.

This is mixed-grass prairie habitat. As the amount of native mixed-grass prairie is shrinking across the west, each block of land set aside for wildlife is important. Many of our endangered species in Manitoba are native to either mixed-grass or tallgrass prairie habitat.

The endangered loggerhead shrike, Baird's sparrow and even the little burrowing owl have been found here. If you are looking for rare and endangered species, Broomhill WMA might provide your only glimpse of one.

Birds of Manitoba identifies the Broomhill WMA and surrounding area as important bird habitat. Some of the species it identifies as nesting here are ferruginous hawk, Say's phoebe, willow flycatcher, upland sandpiper, Sprague's pipits, sharp-tailed grouse, and the non-native gray partridge and ring-neck pheasants.

Broomhill WMA was once largely a mixed-grass prairie with a few stands of willow, aspen and shrubs like prairie rose and silverberry. Because it was cultivated in the past, it now has stands of the invasive non-native grasses like smooth brome. These non-natives grasses are so aggressive they reduce the biodiversity of the site by choking out other species. Today, there is a mix of good and poor quality grasslands in Broomhill.

C. Stuart Stevenson WMA is in the western region of Manitoba, just off Highway 16. Stuart Stevenson's son provided the land for the WMA and asked that it be named for his father. The WMA's main features are three wetlands encircled by grasslands and shrubs, with a few aspen bluffs perched on top of knolls.

C. Stuart Stevenson is a small WMA that protects excellent nesting habitat for waterfowl, yellow warblers, northern orioles and clay-coloured sparrows. You will find deer and grouse year-round.

The WMA is in the heart of pothole country. This is the duck nursery of North America. It is these small ponds, a remnant from the ice age, not the large lakes, which are the vital habitat for waterfowl to raise their young.

Catfish Creek WMA sits on an end moraine or large deposit of sand and gravel left by the last glacier. At a few points you have an elevation of 290 metres that provides a nice view of the landscape. Where Catfish and Jackfish creeks cut through the WMA, the elevation drops below 230 metres. The two creeks drain into Traverse Bay on the eastern edge of Lake Winnipeg.

Catfish Creek WMA provides a diversity of habitats for wildlife, from the creeks up to the sandy hilltops. The vegetation ranges from black spruce, tamarack, ash, alder, willows, sedges, grasses, Manitoba maple, balsam poplar, birch, white spruce, jack pine and mosses. Jack pine stands are a great place to find orchids like the moccasin flower. The local First Nations community uses the area to gather food like berries and mushrooms, as well as medicinal plants. They also hunt and trap in the WMA.

The diversity of habitats means a diversity of wildlife. The WMA has one of highest concentration of neo-tropical migrant birds in North America. These little songbirds migrate every year from their winter homes in South and Central America, to their summer homes here. They breed and raise their young in our forests. Listen for the ovenbird that sings teacher, teacher, teacher or the chestnut-sided warbler that sings please please pleased to meet'cha.

Catfish Creek is also an important breeding area and migration corridor for northern forest owls. Look for the great gray, northern saw-whet and boreal owls. The great grays hunt during the day, as well as night, so you have a better chance of seeing one.

Catfish Creek is a popular hunting area for moose, white-tailed deer and black bear. In the fall, hunters are out walking the bush for ruffed and sharp-tailed grouse or hunkered down at dawn and dusk around the wetlands hoping to bag some of the plentiful waterfowl. If you want to do a little fishing Catfish Creek is better than Jackfish Creek.

Some of the other wildlife you might catch a glimpse of are the red fox, coyotes, mink and if you are very lucky the occasional wolf.

Catfish Creek WMA is part of the Belair Provincial Forest, land that has been set aside for tree harvesting but also provides important wildlife habitat. There is a labyrinth of logging roads through the forest so be sure to use a compass or GPS unit when exploring, and watch for logging trucks.

The North Star Trail cuts through the WMA. It was once the only road into the beaches. You can access it from Highway 304 near the Stead turn off or Highway 59 north of the Grand Beach turn off. When driving the trails, be careful not to get stuck in the areas with deep sand. In some places the trail and logging roads are in poor shape from the heavy trucks.

Catfish Creek WMA is a great place for horseback riding and biking, but be sure to know your route. Caution – you are in bear country.

Cayer WMA is north of the village of Cayer on the west side of Lake Manitoba. This is Parkland habitat, a mix of aspen-oak forest and open grassland meadows. It is ideal habitat for deer that take advantage of the edge-habitat. They find cover in the trees and plenty of natural forage in the meadows. Cayer WMA was established to protect critical winter habitat for deer. They use the WMA for winter shelter and disperse to the surrounding lands in summer. The WMA also provides habitat for ruffed grouse and other bird life.

Churchill is Manitoba's largest WMA. It protects some of our most impressive wildlife habitat. Habitats include polar bear denning grounds and an extraordinary array of bird nesting sites. It is a land that is awe inspiring and fragile.

Churchill WMA is large and remote. Other than the town of Churchill there are no surrounding settlements. The WMA protects an area from the Nelson River estuary up to the southern edge of Wapusk National Park and around the western side to the town of Churchill, surrounding the park. Together with the park they protect 1,996,313 hectares or 19,963 square kilometres of wildlife habitat. This area is significantly increased when you add Cape Tatnam WMA, which meets Churchill WMA at the Nelson River and runs the coastline all the way to the Ontario border.

There is a dramatic change in both plant and animal life in this sub-arctic transition zone. The landscape is varied with a combination of spruce habitat, tundra ponds, marshes, fens, and bogs. The vegetation includes arctic, sub arctic and boreal plant species. To the south, spruce-pine forests dominate, while the northern portion is dominated by open tundra.

The tundra environment seems monotonous at first glance but it is complex and diverse. The plants are well adapted to survive the harsh conditions. Many grow low to the ground, safely under a cover of snow in the winter to avoid the cutting wind. Other adaptations include special colour pigments to attract sunlight even under a light cover of snow, natural anti-freeze chemicals and the ability to eat insects to get nutrients not available in the soil.

The Churchill WMA and Wapusk National Park protect the largest known polar bear maternity denning grounds in the world. In autumn, most polar bears leave the coast and move onto the newly formed ice for the winter hunt, but pregnant females are not with them. In June and July they move inland searching for dens. The females look for a den dug into the soft peat. When she finds a suitable site, she tunnels into an elevated chamber, that helps retain body heat, then the snow seals her in. In December, she gives birth to one or more cubs, depending on her body weight. By March, the cubs are strong enough to face the world. Breaking out of the den, mother and cubs trek back to the sea.

The best time to do a little polar bear watching is during the fall when the bears are congregating along the coast, waiting for the bay to freeze. There are approximately 950 bears in the Western Hudson Bay sub-population and they are hungry. They fast while on land, unless an easy opportunity presents itself. As the largest carnivore on land, the male weighs 300 to 450 kilograms and can run up to 50 kilometres an hour.

Cape Churchill caribou herd, with an estimated population of over 3,000, moves through the Churchill WMA on well-established routes. They move between the forest's winter cover and the open tundra in summer, where they find a little relief from biting bugs. On the tundra, they feed on protein rich sedge, grass and shrubs. In the forests, they dine on lichen, one of the few animals that will eat these slow growing plants. The caribou herd continues to be an important source of food for local people. The Churchill WMA also protects critical bird habitat. Over 225 species of birds have been identified in the region. The converging habitats, from marine to tundra to forest, provide feeding and nesting areas to a diversity of species. This is the nesting ground for many migrating birds such as the tundra swan or eastern prairie population of Canada goose. You will find three types of loons, a raft of gull species, ospreys, eagles, peregrine falcons, gyrfalcons, merlins and snowy owls. Sea ducks such as eiders, long-tailed ducks and scoters are on the bay. The Ross's gull is one of many rare species you can find. You can download species lists from several sources on the Internet.

The WMA also protects habitat for furbearing mammals – arctic fox, lynx, wolverine, marten, ermine, otter, mink and beaver. Trapping is still an important component of the northern lifestyle.

Churchill WMA is a world-famous destination for wildlife viewing and research. The remoteness and potential danger from polar bears are a good reason to visit Churchill WMA under the guidance of established lodges or tour operators. What may be a simple walk along the coast can turn deadly if you come across a bear resting in the rocks. There are many qualified tour companies that can help you plan your trip. Contact Travel Manitoba for more information.

Clematis WMA is spread over several sections of land in the Interlake area. It is part of a collection of WMAs in an area that has not proven to be productive farmland so has been reclaimed for wildlife habitat. The soil is rocky and limestone is at the surface – poor for farming, but great for wildlife. You will find scrub aspen, grassland meadows and several wetlands dominated by sedge and bulrush.

Clematis was set aside for critical winter habitat for deer, but like most WMAs it provides a home and shelter for a variety of species. There are elk in this area of the Interlake so you may find the occasional group grazing in Clematis.

Black bear are not uncommon. When out picking chokecherries or saskatoons watch for signs of bears. They tend to flatten a berry patch and strip leaves along with the berries from a branch. Perhaps the most telling sign is the scat or droppings, full of berries, which they leave behind.

You may see the occasional coyote out hunting the abundant snowshoe hare or grouse.

The underlying karst topography provides excellent habitat for wintering red-sided garter snakes. Karst topography is a type of landscape that forms in limestone bedrock. It is full of cracks and caverns that make great winter dens for the snakes. When the fall air begins to chill the cold-blooded reptiles, they move underground below the frost line to spend the winter. Come the spring, the snakes emerge and migrate to marshes to hunt frogs, toads and rodents.

David G. Tomasson WMA, formerly known as Washow Bay WMA, provides habitat for moose, staging waterfowl and bald eagles. This area of the Interlake is great for watching the bald eagle migration in October. The WMA also provides habitat for the graceful great blue herons, which have a rookery in the area. You have a good chance of seeing them out feeding in the wetlands.

David G. Tomasson served as the chairperson at Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation, chair and member of the Freshwater Regional Harbour Authority Advisory Committee, director and member of the Hecla Village Harbour Authority and member of the National Harbour Authority Advisory Committee.

Deerwood WMA, also known as the Miami unit, sits at the bottom of the Manitoba escarpment south of Miami. It provides a miture of mixed-grass prairie and aspen-oak forest. It is good songbird habitat and important winter shelter for deer.

Delta Marsh is one of the greatest freshwater marshes of the world. It is recognized internationally as a Wetland of International Importance by the Ramsar Convention. The marsh is approximately 25,000 hectares, stretching around the southern edge of Lake Manitoba.

The Delta Marsh WMA includes the publicly owned portion of 11,800 hectares of the marsh, most of which is east of the Portage Diversion. Three smaller blocks are located on the west side of the diversion. From one end to the other, you can't beat the wildlife viewing opportunities.

Delta Marsh WMA provides a unique variety of wildlife habitat. To the north is the vast expanse of Lake Manitoba, large enough to have wind tides and waves that could sink a ship in a storm. A narrow strip of sand and trees form a beach ridge 40 kilometres long that separates the lake and marsh. The marsh itself is a complex of wide shallow bays, islands, sloughs and wet meadows. Inland from the marsh are pastures and grasslands with stands of Manitoba maple and aspen/oak forests. Together these habitats shelter a wonderful range of species, the most impressive of which are the avian species.

Delta Marsh WMA is one of Manitoba's birding hotspots. Finding Birds in Southern Manitoba recommends starting with the Delta Beach or St. Ambroise Provincial Park areas. Both offer easy access and plenty to see.

Spring is lively with the sounds of migrating warblers. In May, they migrate through in waves of thousands. Spring is also a time of mating dances at Delta. One of the most impressive is the water ballet of the courting western grebe.

In summer, warblers skim through the trees of the beach ridge. Some of the rare species are the golden-winged, black-throated, and blue warblers. In the Clandeboye Bay area, be careful where you step on the beach – the tiny endangered piping plover nests here. Sandpipers run in and out of wavelets along the beach, while white pelican flotillas herd minnows to shore and scoop them into their pouches.

At Delta Beach or St. Ambroise, see canvasbacks, blue-winged teal, mallards, gadwalls and other nesting waterfowl. Keep your eyes sharp to see a great blue heron silently stalking a fat leopard frog. Look to the sky for hawks scanning the marsh. Short-eared owls hunt along the southern edge of the marsh at dusk. At night listen for the great horned owl calling huu-hu-hu hooo-hooo.

As the seasons change and fall arrives the birds begin to gather to migrate south again. Delta Marsh is an important staging area for waterfowl during migration. Staging areas are wetlands where waterfowl rest and feed during migration. They may spend as much as a month here before moving on to the next leg of their journey. Waterfowl spend up to 50 per cent of their lives in staging areas. The other 50 per cent is divided between summer and winter habitats.

The skies over Delta Marsh were once black with waterfowl during migration. Today fewer swans, geese and ducks gather here, but there is still an average of over 50,000 birds during migration – globally significant waterfowl concentrations and a sight to see.

The marsh has a long history of waterfowl hunting. Princes and Hollywood celebrities hunted here in the early 1900s. If you are planning to go out for a shoot, be sure to consult your provincial hunting guide for dates, bag limits and areas that are closed. Hunting is not allowed in the Game Bird Refuge. About half of the marsh is privately owned so you must have owner permission to hunt there.

Dog Lake WMA includes the waters of the lake and all the islands within it. The WMA was first established to provide a safe habitat for nesting and migrating waterfowl. The islands have been a designated bird sanctuary since 1957. This WMA demonstrates the importance and success of setting aside wildlife habitat – it has played a significant role in the recovery of the giant Canada goose population.

Today the Dog Lake WMA is internationally recognized as a nesting and staging area for colonial waterbirds. It provides a safe haven for white pelicans, double-crested cormorants, great blue herons and a number of gull species.

This is also the only known great egret colony in Manitoba. The beautiful white egrets nest in the trees among the cormorants, great blue herons, black-crowned night herons, with the pelicans nesting on the ground below – making this our only known five-tiered waterbird colony.

The great egret was on the verge of disappearing in the early 1900s. Their snowy white feathers, used to adorn hats, were worth twice their weight in gold. The National Audubon Society adopted the great egret as its emblem in their push to save the species. Since that time their numbers have increased but they are still a rare sight to see in Manitoba. You might occasionally see them migrating through Whitewater WMA as well (see the section on the Whitewater WMA).

Game bird hunting is prohibited on the islands of the Dog Lake WMA as it is a bird sanctuary

Donald W. Orchard WMA, formerly part of Deerwood WMA, includes the headwaters of Tobacco Creek. The WMA sits right on the edge of the Manitoba escarpment and has an impressive elevation change. The creek cuts down into the side of the escarpment, creating a ravine with some challenging terrain. The hills are covered with significant remnants of mixed-grass prairie and aspen-oak forest. It is good songbird habitat and important winter shelter for deer.

Prior to serving in cabinet, Donald W. Orchard farmed in the Miami area within a few miles of this scenic part of the Pembina Valley.

Dr. Frank Baldwin WMA, formerly Lake Francis WMA, is part of the Delta Marsh complex and borders the eastern edge of the Delta Marsh WMA. Like Delta, Lake Francis and the smaller lakes within this WMA contain very important bird habitat. It is a major breeding and staging area for waterbirds.

Like Delta it stretches along the southern edge of Lake Manitoba and includes a wooded beach ridge behind which is a large wetland. The WMA also has a very special feature – a remnant of endangered tallgrass prairie. Tallgrass prairie, what little remains, is more likely found in the Red River Valley south of Winnipeg. This rare habitat greatly increases the value of the WMA and adds an even greater diversity to Delta Marsh.

Sprague's pipits and other grassland birds can be found in the tallgrass prairie. On the lake you can see large numbers of western grebes and pelicans. The endangered piping plover has been known to nest on the sandy beaches but very few have been found by the Piping Plover Guardians in recent years. Protecting beaches from disturbance until late July will help the endangered plovers raise their young.

The beach ridge is a breeding area and critical migration stopover for variety of warblers. Large numbers gather in spring and fall as they migrate through in waves. The wetlands are used by a diversity of waterbirds. Don't overlook the other wildlife of the marsh like amphibians and reptiles, there are plenty of leopard frogs and painted turtles.

A rare plant species you should watch for on the beach ridge is the hackberry tree. The only other known site in Manitoba that it is found in is near the Lauder Sandhills WMA. The hackberry is a rare species of the elm family.

To explore the tallgrass prairie site you can access it along PR 411. Here you can take a walk through the endangered ecosystem and find a trailhead sign that explain more about the tallgrass prairie.

Dr. Frank Baldwin served on the board of Ducks Unlimited Canada from 1991 through 2005 and following his retirement from the board, served as an emeritus director until his death. During this time, he directed his efforts towards conservation and education initiatives including the opening of the Oak Hammock Marsh Interpretive Centre, Greenwing Days, waterfowl festivals, the Adopt-A-Class program, countless mentored hunts and the Great Greenwing Adventure Camp. He also served on the Selkirk Ducks Unlimited Committee, acting as a chair for over a decade.

Ebor is a small WMA near the Saskatchewan border, between Pipestone and Stony creeks, in the heart of mixed-grass prairie country. Ebor includes many small wetlands that are ideal nurseries for waterfowl. The wetlands provide habitat for marsh wrens, rails, grebes and other waterfowl.

The prairie surrounding the wetlands provides much needed habitat for grassland species, particularly birds. Grassland birds to look for include Say's phoebes, willow flycatchers, loggerhead shrikes, Sprague's pipits, chestnut collared longspurs, Baird's sparrow and lark buntings. You might also find sharp-tailed grouse, along with the non-native ring-necked pheasants and gray partridge.

The land has never been cultivated but it is grazed by cattle. At one time fires regularly raged across grasslands, carried along by the wind and fuelled by dead plant stalks accumulating since the last fire. Today, grassland fires are often suppressed, causing a build up of thatch or dead plant matter. A fire removes the thatch and allows more sunlight to penetrate to the ground. It also releases nutrients. Cattle grazing can accomplish the same effect as a fire if done correctly and can help a grassland habitat.

Ebor WMA includes patches of aspen woodlands that protect a mixed habitat for deer and grouse.

Edward A. Poyser WMA, formerly part of Whitemud Watershed WMA, provides important habitat for deer, upland game birds, amphibians and other wildlife that require mixed-grass prairie and aspen-oak stands. It sits on the Manitoba escarpment area south of MacGregor. Aspen-oak forests dominate the parcels of land on rolling hills of an old glacial moraine.

Ewonchuk WMA is situated just east of Sleeve Lake WMA. The WMA was established to protect habitat for deer, elk and grouse. Aspen and a scattering of white spruce, dominate the ridge and swale landscape.

People and wildlife love the abundance of chokecherries and saskatoons, known as service berries elsewhere. You will also see the colourful red-osier dogwood – but don't eat their white berries – they are strictly for wildlife, too bitter for people. Ewonchuk WMA is a popular breeding and stop-over habitat for migrating neo-tropical birds like the orange-crowned warbler. Watch the roadsides for the eastern bluebird and black-billed cuckoo.

Frank W. Boyd WMA, formerly part of Pierson WMA, provides locally important habitat for deer, sharp-tailed grouse, gray partridge, pheasants and a diversity of grassland birds. Mule deer and pronghorns have been spotted in this WMA – two species once thought to be extirpated from much of Manitoba.

Some birds to watch for include greater white-fronted goose, mountain bluebird, Swainson's and ferruginous hawk, upland sandpiper, willow flycatcher, lark bunting and chestnut-collared longspur.

The WMA is southwest of Pierson. It includes reclaimed cultivated lands, aspen woodlands and small wetlands. The previously cultivated areas were reseeded with grasses to provide permanent wildlife cover. You will also find a few oil wells still in operation on this unit.

Grahamdale WMA is in the Interlake, close to the northern end of Lake Manitoba, east of PTH 6. This is the Interlake Plain Ecoregion. Ridges, 400 to 800 metres wide, were formed by the wave action of the retreating glacial Lake Agassiz. These remnant beaches are oriented in a northwest-southeast direction, reflecting the measured retreat of the lake.

Stunted aspen cover the ridges; poor soils don't allow the aspen to thrive. White spruce and balsam fir are the climax species of this region – the trees that would naturally dominate a forest if there were no fire or harvest to interrupt the forest succession or evolution. Fire is a natural process that still occurs in this WMA, so you will only find a few stands of white spruce and balsam fir.

On dry sandy sites there are stands of tall jack pine, born of the last fire, when the heat released their seeds. Grassy meadows, a few shallow marshes and rock outcrops are interspersed throughout the WMA. Look for elk grazing in the meadows.

Grahamdale WMA is providing habitat for white-tailed deer, black bear, ruffed grouse, beaver, coyote, snowshoe hare and the occasional moose. This is also good habitat for the red-sided garter snake.

Grant's Lake WMA is northwest of Winnipeg, about a half hour drive from the edge of the city. Most of the WMA is a managed wetland – protecting a major waterfowl staging area. On early mornings during spring and fall migration you can see thousands of snow geese covering the wetland before they lift off and head out for a day of foraging. As you near the WMA watch for them in surrounding fields. There are many other waterfowl species that take advantage of the WMA. Watch for shorebirds feeding along the edge of the lake.

The Grant's Lake WMA was developed in cooperation with Ducks Unlimited Canada. This cooperative habitat development project involved excavating several small ponds and creating nesting islands, improving the appeal of the site for nesting as well as a staging area.

The lake itself is a game bird refuge so no hunting is allowed in the WMA. A managed hunting program is available around the perimeter of the WMA. Check the annual Hunting Guide for details.

Gypsumville WMA is between the town and the lake of the same name. The WMA was established to protect habitat for deer, black bear, waterfowl, grouse, muskrat and moose. The habitat is that of typical Interlake – aspen, with a sprinkling of white spruce. Jack pine dominates the dry ridges and black spruce and tamarack in the wet bog.

Moose can be found in the WMA from time to time, feeding in the bogs. Moose are solitary animals. Occasionally you may see more than one feeding in the same area, but it is as if they don't acknowledge each other. In winter, they might tolerate each other a little more as they yard up or gather in a place that provides the winter necessities. Moose are quick to flee if they sense people; any movement tends to send them on their way. Hunters or wildlife watchers should approach from upwind, standing still if it lifts its massive head to check the movement.

Muskrat are a staple of the trapping industry. Water rats, as they are often called, is an appropriate name as they are members of the rodent family. Muskrat are found across North America in a range of aquatic habitats. Ideally the marsh or pond they live in should be deep enough not to freeze in winter or they cannot travel or feed. Trappers look for their push-ups – shelters made of cattails – preferring to trap them in the winter when their coats are lush.

While visiting Gypsumville WMA watch or listen for sandhill cranes. The have a distinctive sound and you can often hear them but not see them, despite their height and noisy bugling. In spring, let their mating calls lead you to them and you will be treated to their elaborate courtship dances.

Harperville WMA is nestled among North, East and West Shoal Lakes in the Interlake Region. The WMA has a diversity of habitats and a corresponding diversity of species taking advantage of the range of niches it protects.

In typical Interlake fashion there are ridges covered with aspen and bur oak. Saskatoon and chokecherry, ripe in July, form the understorey. Between the ridges are grassy meadows and marshes of sedge, cattail and bulrush.

The marsh in Harperville WMA is both a nesting and staging area for waterfowl, shorebirds and other typical marsh birds. WMAs that protect nesting grounds for these species are important, as many nesting areas have been lost to agriculture in the past.

The uplands of Harperville WMA protect habitat for white-tailed deer and ruffed grouse.

Harrison is a small WMA just west of Rolling River First Nation. This is pothole country but the WMA is mostly lush deciduous forest with two forage fields. It is good habitat for white-tailed deer and the occasional elk.

Elk were once very common on the prairies. Early explorers reported hearing them bugling along the Red River. Today you find them in patches of habitat like WMAs or parks, where they can find forage near shelter afforded by stands of trees.

The landscape around the Harrison WMA is a rolling topography, a pleasure to explore. The Trans Canada Trail passes to the north of the WMA. This portion of the TCT is on an abandoned rail bed, known as the Rossburn Line. Once you have visited the WMA take a walk along the trail between Rackham and Sandy Lake. You can find out more about the area, both its natural and cultural features, on the Manitoba Trans Canada Trail guide number one – Western Uplands and Mixed-grass Prairie.

Hilbre WMA butts up against the eastern edge of Portage Bay at the northern end of Lake Manitoba. The topography is gently rolling with ridges dominated by bur oak and aspen. Native grasslands form meadows between the wooded areas giving it a park-like setting.

The native grasslands protect habitat for grassland birds such as the savannah sparrow. The lake's edge is home to the wee sedge wren and the red-winged blackbird whose unmistakable call tells you that you are in a wetland.

The combination of grassland and deciduous forest makes this WMA good habitat for deer and grouse.

Hilltop WMA is a relatively new WMA. It gets its name from the local school district. Hilltop was established in 2006 with the encouragement of local residents who wanted to see the lush forest site set aside for habitat.

Hilltop WMA is west of Otter Lake in a stand of heavy spruce with a mix of birch and aspen. Creeks that flow into the lake cut through the WMA providing a water source for wildlife, an important component of any habitat.

Holmfield WMA was purchased in 1986 to protect an important waterfowl nesting area. Its establishment was a partnership between many leading habitat conservation groups. The partners included Manitoba Habitat Heritage Corporation, Wildlife Habitat Canada, Manitoba Naturalists Society, Manitoba Wildlife Federation and Manitoba Conservation. Ducks Unlimited Canada developed a marsh management project for the WMA to improve its attractiveness to waterfowl.

Approximately one-third of the WMA is a wetland used by a variety of waterfowl to raise their young. Look for mallards, blue-winged teal and Canada geese. Some of the other marsh species you will find are red-winged and yellow-headed blackbirds. The wetland also provides a home to muskrats and western painted turtles.

The rest of Holmfield WMA is primarily mixed-grass prairie with some willow and aspen bush. The prairie provides nesting sites for a variety of grassland species. Listen for the melodic call of the meadowlark. On the prairie you can find weasels lurking, foxes hunting on the sly and deer gazing quietly. At night listen for the yip and howls of coyotes celebrating the evening.

In a sea of agriculture, the Souris River Bend WMA protects one of the largest islands of natural habitat in southwestern Manitoba. Large WMAs are important because they can support a greater diversity of wildlife, including mammals that require large ranges to survive.

The Souris River Bend WMA is considered one of the most scenic landscapes in the region. There are vast tracts of riparian forests and undisturbed tracts of the increasingly rare mixed-grass prairie. Some lands have been reclaimed from cultivation, planted to grasses and trees.

The WMA protects essential habitat for neo-tropical and grassland birds. It is a popular area for birding. Look for Say's and eastern phoebes, willow and great crested flycatchers, brown thrasher, lark sparrow, eastern wood-pewee, rose-breasted grosbeak and yellow-throated vireo. Listen for eastern screech-owl, great horned and long-eared owls in spring. Along the river watch for wood duck, hooded merganser and both bank and northern rough-winged swallows.

You will also find elk, moose and white-tailed deer. There have been occasional sightings of mule deer, thought to be extirpated from Manitoba.

One of the best ways to visit the area, and do a bit of bird watching, is by canoe when the water levels permit. Horseback is another popular way to explore. Trails have been developed in cooperation with a provincial equestrian organization.

Inwood WMA includes two blocks of land in the Interlake. It is part of a series of WMAs in the area, many of which are reclaimed from unproductive farmland. The WMA is typical ridge and swale topography of the Interlake with a mix of aspen woodlands, grasslands and wetlands. This diversity of habitat types makes it attractive for wildlife.

Inwood protects essential habitat for deer, ruffed and sharp-tailed grouse and numerous neo-tropical migrant birds, the little songbirds that come to Manitoba to raise their young. Watch for the orange-crowned warbler in the understorey of saskatoons and chokecherries. Owls such as the great horned owl are frequently seen. Other birds to watch for are the alder flycatcher, clay-coloured sparrow, eastern towhee and sedge and marsh wrens.

Keep a sharp lookout for great egrets when you come to one of the many wetlands. They often range this far from their only known colony at Dog Lake WMA. These rare and beautiful white heron-like birds stand 95 centimetres (37 inches) tall on black stilt-like legs.

Inwood WMA also protects important summer habitat for red-sided garter snakes. When the harmless garter snakes leave their dens in spring they disperse to surrounding wetlands to hunt frogs, minnows, leeches, birds, rodents, even insects. This is also where the females will give birth to their young. Yes give birth. Red-sided garter snakes are one of the few snakes that has live young, others lay eggs. In late July or early August, the female delivers an average of 13 to 26 finger-sized snakes. There is no maternal care, once they are born they hit the ground slithering and keep going. The first year the young stay in the surrounding upland area. It isn't until their second year that they migrate to the dens in the fall. Researchers still aren't sure how they find their way to the dens, never having been there before.

The Old Pioneer Trail provides access to the Inwood WMA. The trail is built on the old Oak Point Subdivision line of the Canadian Northern Railway. The line was officially abandoned in 1990. The trail also roughly follows the Principle Meridian. You can access the trail in the town of Inwood, Argyle or a number of other towns it rolls through from Grosse Isle to Fisher Branch.

John T. Williams WMA, formerly known as Thalberg Bush WMA, is an island surrounded by agriculture. Nestled in the aspen, spruce and tamarack forests you will find grouse, deer, black bear and the occasional moose. The WMA protects an important breeding and migration corridor for northern forest owls such as the great gray owl. It also provides significant habitat for neo-tropical birds.

John T. Williams has served as vicepresident of the Canadian Wildlife Federation’s board of directors, the inaugural chair of the Manitoba Fish and Wildlife Enhancement Fund and is the past-president of the Manitoba Wildlife Federation. He was the 2009 recipient of the Manitoba Wildlife Federation Outdoor Heritage Award and the 2013 recipient of the Manitoba Wildlife Federation Jack Dunlop Memorial Conservation Award.

Just west of the town of Melita is the Gerald W. Malaher WMA. The WMA is named for Gerald Malaher, Manitoba's first Director of Wildlife, then called the Game and Fisheries Branch. Malaher worked much of his life in the north and was responsible for innovations such as the registered trapline system and conservation of barren-ground caribou. He was a forester by training, but cared deeply about the northern people and wildlife. He was named director in 1946 after spending 20 years working in the north and wilder areas of the south. Malaher has been compared to other pioneer conservationists such as Ernest Thompson Seton. You can read more about Malaher in his book The North I Love.

The Gerald W. Malaher WMA was established in 1974, ten years before Malaher's death. It is an example of reclaiming unsuccessful agricultural land for wildlife. The light soils of the area are subject to significant wind erosion. When the land was acquired in 1948 there was little vegetation left, much of it was open sand. It was planted with trees, shrubs, grasses and forage plants and became known as the Melita Cover Plot. A small dam was constructed across a shallow ravine to provide water for wildlife.

Today the WMA is a haven for deer, as well as grassland and forest birds. Malaher's heart was in the north but he would have been pleased to see much needed wildlife habitat created here where so little remains.

Kaskatamagan Sipi Wildlife Management Area lies within the transition zone between boreal forest and Arctic tundra. It features ancient beach ridges with thick layers of glacial till that rise above the surrounding landscape.

The area is dominated by vegetation typical of the Taiga boreal forest that includes stunted black spruce, with varying amounts of dwarf birch, tamarack, willow, Labrador tea, sedges, mosses, and lichens.

Kaskatamagan Sipi Wildlife Management Area supports a diverse and noteworthy mammal population. This site provides winter range for coastal caribou that spend the summers along the Hudson Bay coast. Other mammals typical of the area include moose, black bear, lynx, wolves, snowshoe hare, wolverines and muskrats. Kaskatamagan Sipi Wildlife Management Area is within the breeding ranges of many migratory birds including bald eagles, osprey, Canada geese, and sandhill cranes. It also falls in the northern-most range of the northern leopard frog’s territory in Manitoba.

The site is within the traditional territory of Shamattawa First Nation, who hunt and trap in the area, and will continue to exercise their Aboriginal and treaty rights within the wildlife management area.

Kaskatamagan Sipi Wildlife Management Area will help protect representative or unique natural landscapes in an undisturbed state, and provide recreational opportunities that depend on a pristine environment. The site is categorized as a World Conservation Union (IUCN) protected area management category Ib, that is, a protected area managed mainly for wilderness protection.

Kenneth H. Wark WMA, fromerly the Horod Unit of Parkland WMA, is located on the southern edge of Riding Mountain National Park. It has a large area of reclaimed grasslands and several wetlands. The WMA provides habitat for waterfowl, moose, elk, deer, black bear and grouse. You might also see a wide variety of warblers, many flycatchers, vireos, thrushes and sparrows.

Kenneth H. Wark was a conservation officer who pioneered aerial wildlife enforcement. A pilot for decades, he flew enforcement patrols, wildlife recon, fire patrols and surveys. Much of the enforcement work was at night and Wark risked his life for wildlife and was arguably one of the most skilled pilots in Manitoba. He had a conservation agreement on his farm near Riding Mountain National Park and always maintained the wildlife habitat on his land.

La Vérendrye called this mound on the prairie the Blue Jewel of the Plains when he first saw it in 1738. If you look at Turtle Mountain on a hillshade map that shows elevation, it does look like a turtle swimming in a northwest direction across the border. The Cree called the mound Mikinakwuche, meaning turtle.

The Turtle Mountain WMA is in the area of the turtle's head, west of the park. The WMA was established to protect habitat for deer, ruffed grouse and moose. You might also find the occasional elk browsing in the stands of aspen and balsam poplar. Small wetlands are interspersed across the WMA providing water and edge habitat for a variety of wildlife. Birders can find brown thrashers, eastern towhees and indigo buntings.

Langruth WMA is on the west side of Lake Manitoba, between the big lake and Big Grass Marsh. Before settlement this area was a mosaic of aspen/oak groves and rough fescue grasslands. A fescue grassland includes species such as rough fescue, porcupine grass, wheat grasses, wild oatgrass, prairie smoke or three-flowered aven, seneca root and snowberry. Look for the Baird's sparrow in this habitat.

Langruth was set aside to protect habitat for neo-tropical birds, deer, waterfowl and grouse. The ridge and swale topography, with wetland in low areas and grasslands and aspen-balsam poplar mix in the higher locations, is particularly attractive to the neo-tropical migrants.

The Royal Canadian Air Force used what is now the WMA during WW II as a bombing practice range. Now it provides hunting of a different kind – for deer, waterfowl and grouse.

Lee Lake WMA consists of two large lake basins along with many small wetlands that support a diversity of wildlife. The WMA was originally established to protect habitat for Canada geese, a success story in itself. Today it protects habitat for waterfowl, ruffed grouse, elk and deer.

Lee Lake WMA is a diverse mix of lakes, wetlands, grasslands, aspen forest and the occasional stand of jack pine, white spruce and oak. The diversity of habitat makes it a valuable WMA.

Look for the uncommon yellow rail in the Lee Lake WMA. This rail has been described as looking like a week-old chicken. The yellow rail is secretive – seldom heard and almost never seen – so much sought after for life lists. The Birds of Manitoba recommends you brave the mosquitoes to listen for its call at night in a grassy marsh area. It has a distinctive call – tic-tic, tic-tic-tic. Try tapping coins or pebbles together to call the yellow rail.

Lee River WMA is found in the Boreal Shield Ecoregion. The landscape is a mix of granite bedrock outcrops, rolling upland and bogs. Dense stands of jack pine are common, particularly on the drier sites. Mature mixed forests of black and white spruce, balsam fir, balsam poplar and white birch attract many forest songbirds.

The WMA is a major breeding and migration corridor for northern forest owls, including the great gray, northern saw-whet and boreal owls. Ruffed and spruce grouse are common and you might find the occasional sharp-tailed. The large pileated woodpecker likes mature forests. Watch the skies for bald eagles but don't confuse them with the turkey vulture, which are also common in the area.

Wildlife of the Boreal Shield Ecoregion include moose, black bear, wolf, lynx, red fox and snowshoe hare. Both wolves and coyotes have been known to den in the WMA but wolves seldom tolerate coyotes in their territory. White-tailed deer are common and have displaced the woodland caribou that were once found here.

Little Birch WMA is a large U-shaped block of land with a few smaller units scattered around it. It is located in the Interlake close to Mantagao Lake and Sleeve Lake WMAs. The larger a block of habitat is, the more it can support the larger species and those that require large territories, like moose and wolves. Contiguous habitat is the best but if that is not possible, having several large blocks close to each other is the next best thing. That allows for species moving between blocks to find mates and food.

Within Little Birch there are several smaller wetlands and one large wetland in the swales of the ridge and swale topography. The vegetation is a combination of grassland and aspen-oak woods. Look for yellow rails and Nelson's sharp-tailed sparrow in the wetlands.

The WMA protects habitat for deer, elk and grouse. You might also find the occasional moose. This is black bear country, so watch for bears, especially in spring when mothers do not tolerated people near their cubs.

Lundar WMA includes several parcels of land north of PR 419, west of PTH 6. The WMA protects habitat for deer, elk, black bear, ruffed and sharp-tailed grouse. It is a rich mix of grassy meadows, ridges of aspen forest, lowland marshes and sedge meadows, ideal for ungulates. Elk are scattered in small groups throughout the Interlake. They once were common across the prairies.

In the marshes listen for the marsh wren, the call can be heard day or night. It is a reedy gurgle ending with a rattle – cut-cut-turrrrrr-ur. They create ingenious little nests woven in the reeds. In the grasslands look for Savannah Sparrow. Also in the grasslands you might see bobolinks. The bobolink is black and white, but looks like it is wearing its tuxedo backwards. Its flight is a looping up and down, like it is flying along a scalloped edge.

Another species to listen for is the sandhill crane. They are a loud lot! They nest in shallow wetlands, but are often seen in open fields. These large birds can be heard high above you as they fly over in large flocks.

Mantagao Lake is one of the largest WMAs in the Interlake. The landscape of the WMA tells the story of glaciers – eskers, beach ridges and end moraines. The diverse topography produces a diversity of vegetation – ranging from coniferous forest to lakeshore marsh. Mantagao Lake is the largest waterbody in the WMA, but there are also several smaller ones.

A forest fire raged through much of the WMA in the late 1980s. The fire rejuvenated the forest and now there is a mix of aspen and jack pine stands. Moose, elk and deer are abundant. The elk were successfully reintroduced to this WMA between 1969 and 1973.

Several prairie and eastern forest plant species, which are at their northern limits, are found here. One is the staghorn sumac. The sumac is a shrub, a member of the cashew family, with a cluster of red hairy berries in late summer. Traditionally the berries were used for cough syrup.

Mantagao Lake WMA is also the northern most sighting of the northern red-bellied snake and one of the few places you might find it in abundance. The northern red-bellied snake, while small, can grow up to a length of 40 centimetres (16 inches). It is brown to gray, but has a red underbelly as you might have guessed. Like all of Manitoba's native snakes it is not poisonous, but all snakes can bite if picked up or threatened. The northern red-bellied snake is a secretive species, usually found under logs or rocks in marshes and meadows.

Maple Lake WMA includes a portion of the Maple Lake marsh and a mixed-grass prairie adjacent to the marsh. The WMA protects habitat for both waterfowl and grassland birds

The marsh and mixed-grass prairie provide good bird watching for waterfowl, grasslands species and the occasional grouse or stray non-native ring-necked pheasant.

Marshy Point WMA protects a portion of coastal wetland along the eastern shore of Lake Manitoba. The marsh is an important staging area of waterfowl as they gather to feed on their way to and from their winter and summer homes.

This WMA played a significant role in the reintroduction of giant Canada geese. In the 1950s the giant Canada numbers where very low and many feared the subspecies was on the verge of extinction. Only a few were found at Birch Lake and the Dog Lake WMA. In a pioneering recovery effort, 70 giant Canada geese were released at Marshy Point WMA between 1951 and 1957. Their numbers grew to 350 breeding pairs by 1971. The WMA and surrounding area are a goose refuge and a smaller area is a game bird refuge.

The wetlands are also home to wrens, common yellowthroats, grebes and other waterfowl.

Moose Creek is a large WMA that includes islands in Lake Winnipeg and a large block of land stretching from Fisher Bay to Washow Bay. Moose Creek is also a Provincial Forest so some timber harvesting and tree planting occurs.

A large contiguous block of land such as Moose Creek protects habitat for larger mammals like moose, wolves and black bear. Moose Creek is also home to white-tailed deer. The forest cover includes aspen, balsam poplar, white birch, balsam fir, white and black spruce, jack pine and tamarack. Look for the large pileated woodpecker in the mature stands of forest.

The WMA protects an important migration route for bald eagles and other raptors. Watch for them in March/April and October. The eagles come through in the hundreds, stopping to fish and scavenge on the shores of the great lake. Sandhill cranes and Canada geese nest in the marshy areas of Moose Creek.

Moosehorn is a small WMA just north of Dog Lake WMA. There are two blocks, one of which covers a large portion of Moosehorn Lake – an important staging area for migrating waterfowl. Because of its proximity to Dog Lake WMA, watch for species that nest at Dog Lake, but use Moosehorn to feed, such as herons or great egrets.

The topography is typical Interlake ridge and swale. There are several deep wetlands that protect habitat for a diversity of wildlife. Canada geese, upland sandpipers, northern harriers, short-eared owls and Wilson's phalaropes are some of the species you will find in Moosehorn WMA.

Much of Wakopa WMA was once used for gravel extraction. Today it provides habitat for wildlife, particularly deer and grouse. The land is vegetated with aspen and balsam poplar forests and remnants of mixed-grass prairie. The smattering of wetlands have been known to attract moose to the area. There is no shortage of western painted turtles in the wetlands.

Birders should look for ring-necked ducks and red-necked grebes in the wetlands. Other birds to listen for are black-and-white warbler, morning warbler, indigo bunting, Baltimore oriole, great crested flycatcher and yellow-throated vireo.

attributes.snippet: Manitoba's wildlife lands boundaries feature layers showing Refuges, Special Conservation Areas, and Wildlife Management Areas in Manitoba.

attributes.description:
These feature layers show Refuges, Special Conservation Areas (SCA), and Wildlife Management Areas (WMA) in Manitoba.

Refuges

The purpose of this feature layer is to show the boundaries of all refuges in Manitoba, as designated by the Designation of Wildlife Lands Regulation (171/2001), under The Wildlife Act (C.C.S.M. c. W130). Refuge types include Wildlife Refuge, Game Bird Refuge, Goose Refuge, and Fur Bearing Animal Refuge. The Use of Wildlife Lands Regulation (77/99) determines prohibited activities in each refuge.


Boundaries are drawn, based on the physical description described in the regulation, or imported using CAD files from the official Director of Surveys Plan, as stated in the regulation.


Fields included (Alias (Field Name): Field description.)

  • OBJECTID (OBJECTID): Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated
  • Name (NAME): Wildlife Refuge name
  • Type (TYPE): Wildlife Refuge type
  • D of S Plan (D_OF_S_PLA): Director of Surveys plan number
  • Ownership (OWNERSHIP): Land ownership information
  • Area (hectares) (AREA_HA): Area in hectares
  • Hunting Restrictions (HUNTING_RESTRICTIONS): Special restrictions on hunting and trapping of all or particular species that apply in individual refuges

This Refuge layer is meant primarily for display in the Manitoba Wildlife Lands web-mapping application. To download the official Refuge dataset, please refer to the Manitoba Maps Refuge feature layer.


Special Conservation Areas

The purpose of this feature layer is to show the boundaries of all Special Conservation Areas (SCA) in Manitoba, as designated by the Designation of Wildlife Lands Regulation (171/2001), under The Wildlife Act (C.C.S.M. c. W130). Special Conservation Areas are designated to conserve and protect particular species and habitats throughout Manitoba. The Use of Wildlife Lands Regulation (77/99) determines prohibited activities in each Special Conservation Area.


Boundaries are drawn based on CAD files from the official Director of Surveys Plan, as stated in the regulation.


Fields included (Alias (Field Name): Field description.)

  • OBJECTID (OBJECTID): Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated
  • Name (NAME): Special Conservation Area name
  • D of S Plan (D_OF_S): Director of Surveys plan number
  • Area (hectares) (AREA_HA): Area in Hectares
  • Species (SPECIES): Species name
  • Restrictions (RESTRICTIONS): Special restrictions on activities that may occur within special conservation areas

This Special Conservation Area layer is meant primarily for display in the Manitoba Wildlife Lands web-mapping application. To download the official Special Conservation Area dataset, please refer to the Manitoba Maps Special Conservation Area feature layer.


Wildlife Management Areas

The purpose of this feature layer is to show the boundaries of all Wildlife Management Areas (WMA) in Manitoba, as designated by the Designation of Wildlife Lands Regulation (171/2001) under The Wildlife Act (C.C.S.M. c. W130). The Manitoba Wildlife Act provides for the designation of Crown lands as Wildlife Management Areas for the "better management, conservation and enhancement of the wildlife resource of the province."


Wildlife Management Areas exist for the benefit of wildlife and people's enjoyment. The areas play an important role in biodiversity conservation and provide for a variety of wildlife-related forms of recreation. Hunting and trapping are generally permitted in WMAs, but these activities may be prohibited or restricted in a few areas. The use of vehicles, off-road vehicles, watercraft, power boats, or airboats, may be restricted in some areas. Each WMA has its own set of restrictions in place to protect the integrity of the area.


Boundaries are defined using the best available maps. The file is revised and updated on a continual basis.


Fields included (Alias (Field Name): Field description.)

  • OBJECTID (OBJECTID): Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated
  • Name (NAME_E): Wildlife Management Area name
  • Nom (NOM_F): Wildlife Management Area name, in French
  • D of S Plan (D_OF_S): Director of Surveys plan number
  • Sub-Unit (UNIT_SUB): Individual parcel names within larger Wildlife Management Area complexes, where applicable
  • Location (LOCATION): General location based on surrounding landscape
  • Description (DESCRIPTION): Information on ecology, history, tourist attractions and infrastructure within individual Wildlife Management Areas
  • Vehicle Restrictions (VEHICLE_RESTRICTIONS): Special vehicle and travel restrictions that apply within individual Wildlife Management Areas
  • Designated Trail Map (DES_TRAIL_MAP): Maps of official designated trail systems within particular Wildlife Management Areas, when available
  • Walking Trail Map (WALK_TRAIL_MAP): Maps of recognized and maintained walking or other recreational trail systems within particular Wildlife Management Areas, when available
  • Game Species in this WMA (GAME_SPP): Game species that may occur in individual Wildlife Management Areas
  • Hunting Restrictions (HUNTING_RESTRICTIONS): Special restrictions on hunting and trapping of all or particular species that apply in individual Wildlife Management Areas
  • Furbearer Species in this WMA (Fur_spp): Furbearer species that may occur in individual Wildlife Management Areas

This Wildlife Management Area layer is meant primarily for display in the Manitoba Wildlife Lands web mapping application. To download the official Wildlife Management Area dataset, please visit the Manitoba Land Initiative's Administrative Boundaries page.

attributes.description:
Game Hunting Areas (GHAs) are defined under the Hunting Areas and Zones Regulation (220/86) of The Wildlife Act (CCSM c. W130). Game Hunting Areas are used to support boundaries for species-specific hunting seasons, harvest allocations, bag limits and associated regulations. Refer to the Hunting Areas and Zones Regulation for GHA boundary descriptions.


Fields included (Alias (Field Name): Field description)
  • OBJECTID (OBJECTID): sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated
  • GHA (GHA): the number assigned to each Game Hunting Area
  • Shape_Length (Shape_Length): the length of the feature in internal units
  • Shape_Area (Shape_Area): area of the feature in internal units squared

Hunters who harvest a white-tailed deer within two (2) townships (20 km) of the United States border are requested to submit biological samples as part of the CWD surveillance program. The complete head and upper neck is required. Antlers can be removed. When removing antlers a shallow v-notch cut should be made through the skull. This cut should be no deeper than the midpoint of the eye socket.

Submission of Biological Samples are Requested - Hunters who harvest a white-tailed deer in GHAs 17A, 26 or 36 are requested to submit the head to a Drop-Off Depot at the Lac du Bonnet, Pine Falls or Seven Sisters Manitoba Conservation Officer Service District Office. Hunters are asked not to remove the antlers before submitting the head. If the specimen is a male, hunters will be asked when submitting the head whether they wish to retain the antlers and arrangements will be made for their return. These samples can be frozen. These samples will be examined for the presence of brainworm.

Bag Limit = One Wolf and One Coyote
Fall and winter seasons

Gray wolves and coyotes can be hunted under the authority of any Big Game licence. If hunting in a GHA while the area is open to other Big Game species, the wolf or coyote hunter must have a licence and unused game tag (personal or party), which is valid for that area, species and time period. Where the other Big Game hunting seasons are closed, a resident may hunt wolves or coyotes provided he/she is in possession of a used or unused white-tailed deer, elk, moose, black bear or caribou licence. The hunter’s big game licence number is all that is required to possess a wolf or coyote taken under the authority of that licence.

Non-resident (Canadian) and Foreign Resident wolf and coyote hunting opportunity may be available. See the annual Hunting Guide for more information.

Bag Limit = Two Wolves and One Coyote
Fall and winter seasons

Gray wolves and coyotes can be hunted under the authority of any Big Game licence. If hunting in a GHA while the area is open to other Big Game species, the wolf or coyote hunter must have a licence and unused game tag (personal or party), which is valid for that area, species and time period. Where the other Big Game hunting seasons are closed, a resident may hunt wolves or coyotes provided he/she is in possession of a used or unused white-tailed deer, elk, moose, black bear or caribou licence. The hunter’s big game licence number is all that is required to possess a wolf or coyote taken under the authority of that licence.

Non-resident (Canadian) and Foreign Resident wolf and coyote hunting opportunity may be available. See the annual Hunting Guide for more information.

Hunters who harvest a wolf in GHAs 18 - 18C, 23, 23A and 26 are requested to submit: the lower jaw, with teeth attached; a 2.5 sq. cm. (1”x1”) sample of hide with at least 50 guard hairs from the groin or upper hind leg; and a 5 cm. (2”) cube of muscle to any Manitoba Conservation Officer Service District Office. When submitting your sample, you will be expected to provide the date of kill, exact location of the kill, sex of the animal and contact information.

attributes.description:
This data set contains the weekly ranges of prices paid for cattle and volumes sold at Manitoba livestock auction marts in the current year.

Manitoba Agriculture and Resource Development collects Manitoba market cattle prices from local auction marts, and they are compiled and released weekly. This table contains the highest and lowest prices for different weight and sex categories of cattle and the total number of cattle sold at each auction mart, each week in the current year. Each weekly dataset contains the prices and number of head sold for each sale that occurred from Friday to Thursday (data collection usually occurs on Fridays). Historical data is not presented in this table.

This table is used in the Manitoba Cattle Prices and Head Sold dashboard.

Fields included (Alias (Field name): Field description.)

  • Week (Week): This is a serial number associated with each week in the current year. Each week contains data related to sales that occurred from Friday to Thursday, i.e. Week 1 of 2021 represents sales between Friday, Jan. 1, 2021 and Thursday, Jan. 7, 2021, with the corresponding report published by the department on Friday, Jan. 8, 2021.
  • Auction (Auction): This is the location of the auction mart.
  • Parameter (Parameter): This is the data collected from the auction marts. Legend:
    • Head sold: number of head sold
    • Bull: bulls
    • D1: D1 or D2 Cows
    • D3: D3 Cows
    • H401: heifers weighing 401 to 500 pounds
    • H501: heifers weighing 501 to 600 pounds
    • H601: heifers weighing 601 to 700 pounds
    • H701: heifers weighing 701 to 800 pounds
    • H801: heifers weighing 801 to 900 pounds
    • H901: heifers weighing more than 900 pounds
    • S401: steers weighing 401 to 500 pounds
    • S501: steers weighing 501 to 600 pounds
    • S601: steers weighing 601 to 700 pounds
    • S701: steers weighing 701 to 800 pounds
    • S801: steers weighing 801 to 900 pounds
    • S901: steers weighing more than 900 pounds
  • Measure (Measure): The price measure (low or high) indicates whether the price is the lowest or highest for the given category. This is left blank if the parameter is Head sold.
  • Value (Value): This is the number of heads if the parameter is head sold. The price is in Canadian dollars per 100 pounds for other parameters.
